Hammersley |author=David R. Wood}}</ref> was a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[mathematician]] best known for his foundational work in the theory of [[self-avoiding walks]] and [[percolation theory]]. He was born in [[Helensburgh]] in [[Dunbartonshire]], and educated at [[Sedbergh School]]. He started reading [[mathematics]] at [[Emmanuel College, Cambridge]] but was called up to join the [[Royal Artillery]] in 1941. During his time in the army he worked on [[ballistics]]. He graduated in mathematics in 1948. He held a number of positions, both in and outside academia. His book ''Monte Carlo Methods'' with David Handscomb was published in 1964. He was an advocate of [[problem solving]], and an opponent of abstraction in mathematics, taking part in the [[New math]] debate. He was a Fellow (later Professorial Fellow) of [[Trinity College, Oxford]] from 1961, Reader in Mathematical Statistics at [[Oxford University]] from 1969, and elected [[Fellow of the Royal Society]] in 1976. ==See also== * [[Constructions of low-discrepancy sequences#The Hammersley set|Hammersley set]] * [[Hammersley-Clifford theorem]] * [[Low-discrepancy sequence]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Authority control|VIAF=107124894}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Hammersley, John | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 21 March 1920 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Helensburgh]] | DATE OF DEATH = 2 May 2004 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hammersley, John}} [[Category:1920 births]] [[Category:2004 deaths]] [[Category:Alumni of Emmanuel College, Cambridge]] [[Category:People educated at Sedbergh School]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society]] [[Category:Probability theorists]] {{UK-mathematician-stub}}
